JPSartre12

Yesterday, we took my son's car to a race at MidMichigan Motorplex. After a scary first pass in which the traction was questionable and I watched the car cross the finish line almost sideways (I could see the driver's side door from the starting line....not a good feeling.), he ran a best of 8.78@161mph. Later in the day, he attempted to better that mark but the engine grenaded at ~1000' mark and all we saw was smoke for a couple of anxious minutes. 
 Thankfully, as I was about to panic on the starting line, my cell phone rang and it was my son. He told me that he had managed to stay off the wall despite oil being thrown all over his tires at close to 150mph. (He crossed the finish line in 9 seconds spewing oil all over the place.)
 http://files.filefront.com/blown+up+wmvwmv/;5988359;;/fileinfo.html
 http://files.filefront.com/8secpass+wmvwmv/;5988311;;/fileinfo.html
 
 Today, we started the post mortem. It appears that a rod let loose after spinning a rod bearing, taking out part of the oilpan and cylinder sleeve. The block, 2 rods and at least one piston are toast. emoticon_cry

post_info.post_title: The Highs and Lows of Drag racing

Dono

He ran a best of 8.78@161mph. 

 Great time, sounds like that ol' mill was really dialed in.... shame it let go.
JPSartre12

Great time, sounds like that ol' mill was really dialed in.... shame it let go.

 
 It was sweet while it lasted. Son's already looking at replacement that will be faster and more bullet-proof, LS-6 with a dry sump. emoticon_xgood
georged

It was sweet while it lasted. Son's already looking at replacement that will be faster and more bullet-proof, LS-6 with a dry sump. emoticon_xgood

 
 Does he have a decent sponsor? I was briefly toying with the thought of an LS6 for my '57 and early, stock crate long blocks were $5k at dealer cost. By the time it was modded and equipped I would have been in it for $10k.
JPSartre12

Does he have a decent sponsor? I was briefly toying with the thought of an LS6 for my '57 and early, stock crate long blocks were $5k at dealer cost. By the time it was modded and equipped I would have been in it for $10k.

 
 
 No sponsors yet. This season was our debugging season. emoticon_cry 
 
 The LS-6 is a great choice. The block is stronger than the LS-1 and LS-2 and doesn't cost a fortune like the LS-7. emoticon_xgood
georged

No sponsors yet. This season was our debugging season. emoticon_cry 
 
 The LS-6 is a great choice. The block is stronger than the LS-1 and LS-2 and doesn't cost a fortune like the LS-7. emoticon_xgood

 
 I think the LS series is the epitome of mass produced, old technology small block engine development. My only personal experience was a 2000 SS LS1 and the engine was most impressive, to the point of taking a very close look at that engine series. Not close enough to live with another 'Vette, but close. 
 
 If he's after a dealer of anything GM partial sponsorship, if they have some co-op advertising money available, I'd shoot for the LS7. It would also be fodder for magazines and brand forums.
JPSartre12

I think the LS series is the epitome of mass produced, old technology small block engine development. My only personal experience was a 2000 SS LS1 and the engine was most impressive, to the point of taking a very close look at that engine series. Not close enough to live with another 'Vette, but close. 

 
 I have a 396 stroked LT-1 with Callies crank, Manley rods, JE Pistons, big cam, etc., in the same year car as my son's but it'll never come close to the performance of a similarly equipped LS motor because the LS heads flow so much better than the LT-1. The most expensive LT-1 heads flow about the same as stock LS heads, IIRC. I'd never put another LT-1 motor in my car if this one gives up the ghost and this motor has been together for 7 years now without any problems. The heads make the power and the LS heads are lightyears better than previous generations. 
 

 If he's after a dealer of anything GM partial sponsorship, if they have some co-op advertising money available, I'd shoot for the LS7. It would also be fodder for magazines and brand forums.

 
 It's worth a shot to try. emoticon_xgood 
 
 
 I agree that the LS-7 would be the way to go, but a very expensive one at that.
georged

I run only street engines and have always preferred big blocks for my addiction. 475-500 reliable HP is easy to make without high rpms and their destructive wear. I put that together, complete, for the $5k crate cost of an LS6 without the additional $5k of required LS6 accessories.
JPSartre12

I run only street engines and have always preferred big blocks for my addiction. 475-500 reliable HP is easy to make without high rpms and their destructive wear. I put that together, complete, for the $5k crate cost of an LS6 without the additional $5k of required LS6 accessories.

 
 
 In a 57, where you have the room and can take the weight, I agree. In a 94Z28, you have to do a lot of "metal finessing" to get a big block in and keep the car from becoming front heavy.
 My son was considering a Shaffirof big block before he went for the twins. I'm a fan of cubes, too, but it's nice to dial in a specific power level via a computer.emoticon_xgood

 That was one of my son's buddies standing next his friend that was videoing. I'm the one directing the car on the track and arming the datalogger after the burnout.
jim's trucking

I really hate to see race engines go "poot" like that. I'm guessing that's why they say, "Ya gotta Love it!"
 
 The smoke at the finish line reminds me of when I visited some friends in Indianapolis one summer when the SummerNationals were being held there. I was standing at the finish line when Tommy Ivo made an exhibition run in his 4-engine Buick (there was nobody else in that class)...all I could see when he left the starting line was SMOKE!
JPSartre12

I really hate to see race engines go "poot" like that. I'm guessing that's why they say, "Ya gotta Love it!"
 
 The smoke at the finish line reminds me of when I visited some friends in Indianapolis one summer when the SummerNationals were being held there. I was standing at the finish line when Tommy Ivo made an exhibition run in his 4-engine Buick (there was nobody else in that class)...all I could see when he left the starting line was SMOKE!

 
 Ah yes, "TV" Tommy Ivo, a drag racing legend. emoticon_xgood
